page.title: 20LOCAL HISTORY OF TIDWORTH II
page.content: The estates were eventually sold to the War Department in l897. Work on building the barracks began in l902 and a railway spur was built to trans- port men and stores.The eight barracks were named after battles in India and many roads bear Indian names.Americans came to Tidworth in l942 and many GI brides left from Tidworth in l946. This account of Tidworth has been completed by Mrs.Sharon Garrick,wife of an Army Officer; Mrs.Denise Wiggell and Captain John Wiggell,Royal Army Ordnance Corps; Mrs.Sybil Baugh, President Tidworth Womens Institute; Mrs.Margaret Wadcock,Church Secretary; Mrs.Mary Otway and Mr.Ted Otway, Churchwarden of Holy Trinity Church and Robert Lewis,Photographer. Tidworth,one of the oldest villages in England lives on, serving the country as it always has for so long.
